title: During World War II, when the Japanese were on the offensive in the Pacific and winning on all fronts, at any time did they approach the Americans requesting talks? Or, was it an all or nothing deal? - Quora

response.answer_text: During World War II, when the Japanese were on the offensive in the Pacific and winning on all fronts, at any time did they approach the Americans requesting talks? No, they did not. Their assumption was that after Pearl Harbor the US would roll over and negotiate. They were surprised when the US did not. After their tremendous initial success, they were stunned when the US defeated the Imperial Navy at Midway, and astonished at the ferocity with which the US defended, attacked and counter-attacked them. Their propaganda was that the Americans were cowards with no fighting spirit. The Japanese government made no attempt what-so-ever to contact the US government about the status of the war until July, 1945. If you know of such an attempt, please supply citations and detailed supporting information so that we can all see what actually happened, there are many incorrect rumors and myths about this.

Q: During World War II, when the Japanese were on the offensive in the Pacific and winning on all fronts, at any time did they approach the Americans requesting talks? Or, was it an all or nothing deal? The people who start the war rarely ask for peace while they’re winning. In fact, I don’t recall that ever happening. It’s not an “all or nothing deal”, it’s how winning and losing work in a shooting war. Besides, asking for peace talks suggest a weakness the opponent isn’t aware of. It usually makes your opponent think things are changing to their benefit so they can fight some more.
